flow.context: Denise Turner is the Owner & Operator of Grand Welcome Palm Springs — she is the top local decision-maker for any operational tooling. She has 30+ years in property management with a background in business administration, leadership, and marketing. Her team runs in-house housekeeping, maintenance, and does spot-checks and top-to-bottom inspections before guests arrive. Grand Welcome is a franchise brand (750+ properties nationwide as of 2022) with a proprietary reservation system; no public PMS or ops platform was found for the Palm Springs location, and unit count is unknown. Strongest Sam connection: both are SoCal natives — Sam grew up in La Cañada (LA area), Denise operates in the Coachella Valley. Secondary hook: Sam's parents are physicians, Denise has chaired walks for the Alzheimer's Association.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Denise, I work with a few property managers out in the Coachella Valley — I'm actually from the LA area originally, grew up in La Cañada. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Warm, relaxed tone. Feet-up energy. Don't rush — let the SoCal connection land before you ask the question. Smile.

branches.label: No, I haven't heard of you
Who is this? / What's this about?

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — TRANSITION TO PAIN
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason I'm calling — I work with a few other full-service managers running a pretty similar setup to yours. In-house cleaning crew, maintenance team, doing those spot-checks and top-to-bottom inspections before guests show up. And what keeps coming up is that even with solid people doing walk-throughs, stuff slips through. A chipped countertop here, a stained cushion there — and nobody catches it until a guest drops it in a review or an owner calls asking why their place looks different than last time they visited. The real cost isn't even the repair — it's the owner trust you can't get back and the review that's already live.
heard_no.note: PAUSE here. Let the pain sit. Do not rush to the solution. Wait for her to react — she'll either relate, push back, or ask what you do.

branches.label: Yeah, that happens / tells a story
We actually have a good process for that

heard_yes.label: HEARD THE NAME — EXPLORE
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What did you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, use it to transition naturally into pain or discovery.

branches.label: Actually, I'm not sure / confused with someone else

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday morning?
bad_timing.note: Don't push. Get a specific callback time. If she says Friday, lock it in.

branches.label: Sure, try me Thursday / gives a time

callback_locked.label: CALLBACK CONFIRMED
callback_locked.say: Perfect — I'll give you a ring Thursday morning. Really appreciate it, Denise. Talk soon.
callback_locked.note: Log the callback time immediately. Do not try to pitch now — you earned the callback, protect it.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION REQUEST
permission_fallback.say: Yeah, totally fair — it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
permission_fallback.note: Disarming honesty. Most people will give you 30 seconds when you name what's happening.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED — SPLIT
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not a fit?
permission_rejected.note: This splits the objection. Timing gets you a callback. Not a fit gets you info you can work with.

pain_positive.label: THEY RELATE — DISCOVERY
pain_positive.say: Yeah — that's exactly what I keep hearing. So I'm curious, what does your inspection process look like right now? Are your cleaners taking photos after every turnover, or is it more your team doing walk-throughs before check-in?
pain_positive.note: STOP PITCHING. She's warm — ask questions. Learn her current workflow before you position anything.

branches.label: We do spot-checks and top-to-bottom inspections

discovery_deep.label: DEEPER DISCOVERY
discovery_deep.say: Got it. And when something does get missed — a broken tile, a stain on a sofa that wasn't there before — how do you usually find out? Is it the owner flagging it, the next guest, or does your team catch it on the following turnover?
discovery_deep.note: You're building the case for why the current process has gaps. Whatever she says, it leads to solution. If she says they catch everything, respect it and probe gently.

branches.label: Admits things get missed / it's usually the owner or guest

discovery_volume.label: VOLUME & SCALE QUESTION
discovery_volume.say: Makes sense. How many properties are you managing right now across the valley? I'm trying to get a sense of the volume your team's dealing with on turnovers.
discovery_volume.note: Unit count was not public — this is critical info. Also helps you tailor the solution and pricing later.

branches.label: Why do you need to know that?

solution_bridge.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_bridge.say: So here's the short version — we built something that takes the photos your team's already taking during turnovers and automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues. No workflow change — it just plugs into whatever system you're already running. Catches stuff before guests see it or owners hear about it.
solution_bridge.note: One breath. Don't elaborate unless she asks. Let her react. If she asks how it works, that's buying signal — go to CTA.

branches.label: That's interesting / how does it work?
We already have a process for that
I don't think we need that

cta_meeting.label: LOW-FRICTION CTA
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to taking a look sometime when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue? Even just 15 minutes — I can walk you through what a couple other managers in the desert are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
cta_meeting.note: The meeting is worth her time even if she never buys. Don't oversell. Competitive intel is the real value prop.

branches.label: Sure / yeah I'd be open to that
I don't really have time right now
I'd need to loop in my GM / team

booking_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
booking_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — how does Tuesday or Wednesday afternoon look? I'm thinking like 15 minutes, super casual.
booking_meeting.note: Pick a day and time. Lock it in NOW. Do not leave it open-ended.

branches.label: Can we do the week after?
Actually just send me an email first

meeting_confirmed.label: MEETING LOCKED — GET EMAIL
meeting_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll shoot you a calendar invite right now. What's the best email for you — is it the hello at palmspringsmanagement one, or do you have a direct one?
meeting_confirmed.note: Get her direct email if possible. Send the invite WHILE on the phone so it's locked. Once booked, STOP SELLING.

meeting_close.label: CLOSE — MEETING BOOKED
meeting_close.say: Done — just sent it. Really appreciate you taking my call, Denise. Looking forward to it. Talk soon.
meeting_close.note: Stop here. Don't add anything. Don't pitch. You won. Log everything immediately.

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That totally makes sense — with an in-house team doing spot-checks and top-to-bottom inspections, you'd have to have something solid in place. I'd actually expect that from someone with 30 years in the business.
objection_have_process.note: Agree first. Validate her experience specifically. Don't fight the objection — she's reacting to the interruption, not rejecting the product.

split_have_process.label: SPLIT — PROCESS OBJECTION
split_have_process.say: Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that your team's catching everything and you're fully covered, or is it more that adding anything new right now would just be a headache on top of everything else?
split_have_process.note: The split forces her to pick one. Either answer gives you something to work with.

branches.label: It's more that adding something new is a pain

test_drive_process.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive_process.say: Totally fair. You're probably not buying anything on a cold call — I respect that. But the managers I talk to who stay sharpest about this stuff are the ones who already know what's out there before they need it. If nothing else, I could walk you through what some other operators in the valley are doing with their turnover photos — one of the bigger ones is actually using AI to catch things their walk-throughs miss. Worst case you see what the competition's up to and we part as friends.
test_drive_process.note: Reframe from 'buy my thing' to 'know what's out there.' Competitive intel about other Palm Springs operators is the real value hook for Denise as owner.

branches.label: Okay, sure / that could be useful
Send me an email about it

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would've reached out yourself.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree. Don't push. The agree-and-split is your only move here.

split_not_interested.label: SPLIT — NOT INTERESTED
split_not_interested.say: Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that inspections just aren't a priority right now, or is it more that you hate cold calls? Because honestly, I get both.
split_not_interested.note: Light humor. If it's cold calls, pivot to email. If it's priority, probe what IS the priority.

branches.label: It's the cold call / just send info
It's not a priority / we're good

test_drive_not_interested.label: LAST SHOT — VALUE OFFER
test_drive_not_interested.say: Totally hear you. One last thing and I'll let you go — I put together a quick breakdown of what some of the other operators in the Palm Springs market are doing with their inspection workflows. Happy to send it over, no strings. If it's useful, great. If not, at least nobody cold calls you about this again.
test_drive_not_interested.note: Free competitive intel — very low ask. Gets your foot in the door for email follow-up.

deflect_cost.label: COST QUESTION — DEFLECT TO MEETING
deflect_cost.say: Good question — honestly it depends on how many units you're running and what your turnover frequency looks like. That's part of why I was hoping to do a quick call — I can give you real numbers based on your portfolio instead of a generic range. Would you be open to 15 minutes sometime this week?
deflect_cost.note: Never quote price on a cold call. Deflect to meeting. Cost question is a buying signal — she's interested enough to ask.

deflect_cost_firm.label: COST — FIRM PUSH
deflect_cost_firm.say: Honestly, the range is pretty wide depending on unit count — I've seen it be anywhere from a couple hundred bucks a month to well over a thousand. Really comes down to how many properties and how often turnovers happen. Quickest way to get you a real number is a 15-minute call where I can ask a few questions. How's later this week look?
deflect_cost_firm.note: Give a wide range so she can't anchor. Immediately redirect to the meeting. Don't let this become a pricing negotiation.

branches.label: Let me think about it / send info

objection_timing.label: OBJECTION — TIMING
objection_timing.say: This one's on me — if you were totally ready for something like this, you probably would have reached out. But the operators I talk to who are sharpest about this stuff are the ones who evaluate early so they know what's on their list when the time's right. Even just 15 minutes — would later this week or next week be less crazy?
objection_timing.note: Reframe: evaluating now is smart even if buying later. Offer specific timing options.

branches.label: Send me something and I'll look at it

referral_gm.label: REFERRAL — LOOP IN GM/TEAM
referral_gm.say: That makes total sense. Would that be Justin, your GM? I'm happy to loop him in — or if it's easier, I can set something up with both of you on the line. That way we cover the ops side and the business side in one shot.
referral_gm.note: You know Justin Marché is GM from research. Using his name shows you've done your homework and builds credibility. Signals to Denise you're serious.

branches.label: Yeah, include Justin / gives another name
Let me talk to him first and get back to you
Actually, talk to Stacy — she handles ops
This would need to go through Grand Welcome corporate

booking_meeting_with_referral.label: BOOK MEETING WITH REFERRAL
booking_meeting_with_referral.say: Perfect. Let me get something on the calendar with both of you — how does next week look? I'm flexible on timing.
booking_meeting_with_referral.note: A meeting with Denise AND Justin or Stacy is gold. Lock it in immediately. Get both emails for the invite.

branches.label: Send us an email and we'll coordinate

referral_stacy.label: REFERRAL TO STACY
referral_stacy.say: Oh great — Stacy Bottroff? I saw she's been in the vacation rental space for a long time. Would it be cool if I mention you pointed me her way?
referral_stacy.note: Use Stacy's full name to confirm. Getting Denise's permission to name-drop is a warm intro for the next call.

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL LOCKED
referral_confirmed.say: Awesome — I appreciate that, Denise. I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands with her. Thanks for your time — talk soon.
referral_confirmed.note: Log the referral immediately. Prep a personalized flow for the referred contact before calling them.

objection_corporate.label: OBJECTION — FRANCHISE / CORPORATE DECISION
objection_corporate.say: Oh interesting — so does tooling like this get decided at the Grand Welcome corporate level, or do you have autonomy on the ops side for your Palm Springs operation?
objection_corporate.note: Grand Welcome is a franchise. Local operators often have full autonomy for operational tools. Probe before assuming corporate blocks the deal.

branches.label: I have autonomy / I decide locally
Depends on what it is / some things I decide

referral_corporate.label: REFERRAL TO CORPORATE
referral_corporate.say: Got it — do you know who at Grand Welcome corporate would be the right person to talk to about something like this? If I can get a name, I'll put something tailored together so it actually makes sense for the franchise model.
referral_corporate.note: Get a name and title at corporate. Also ask if Denise would be willing to intro or if you should go cold.

branches.label: I don't know / try their main line

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question so I don't just send you a generic pitch — what would be most relevant to include? Is it more about how it works with your current workflow, or would you rather see what kind of stuff it actually catches?
send_email.note: Accept the email request, then ask one question to tailor it. This also keeps her talking.

branches.label: Tells you what she wants to see
Just send me whatever / general info

email_close.label: EMAIL — GET ADDRESS AND CLOSE
email_close.say: Done — I'll send that over today. What's the best email? Is it the hello at palmspringsmanagement one, or do you have a direct inbox? And I'll throw a time suggestion in there for a quick call in case anything jumps out — no pressure at all.
email_close.note: Get direct email if possible. Always suggest a specific meeting time in the email. Follow up within 2 hours of hanging up.

email_final.label: EMAIL CLOSE
email_final.say: Perfect. I'll get that over to you this afternoon. Appreciate your time, Denise. Talk soon.
email_final.note: Send the email within 1 hour. Include competitive intel about Palm Springs market operators. Suggest a specific meeting time 3-4 days out. Follow up by phone if no reply in 3 business days.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to Denise? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Minimum info. First name only for the lead. Your first name only. Sound like you belong.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property managers out in the Coachella Valley. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still no pitch. Don't explain what RapidEye does. Let them assume you're someone she'd know.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Sure thing — I help a couple other property management companies in the desert with their inspection workflows. I sent her a note already — would you mind just giving her a heads up that Sam Parks called? And when's the best time to catch her?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Third pass. Get a callback time. If they push further, gracefully accept the message and move on.

branches.label: Gives best time to call back

gatekeeper_unavailable.label: GATEKEEPER — UNAVAILABLE
gatekeeper_unavailable.say: No worries at all — when's the best time to catch her? I don't want to keep calling at the wrong time.
gatekeeper_unavailable.note: Get specific timing — morning vs. afternoon, which days. Log it for your next attempt.

gatekeeper_close.label: GATEKEEPER — CLOSE
gatekeeper_close.say: Appreciate it — I'll try her again. Thanks for your help.
gatekeeper_close.note: Be genuine. Log the interaction. Try again at a different time of day. Consider emailing Denise directly to warm up the next attempt.

ending_graceful.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
ending_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Denise.
ending_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Stay warm. Log the call and set a re-approach reminder for 60-90 days out.
